{{POV|date=July 2016}} '''Narrative medicine''' is a [[medicine|medical]] approach that utilizes people's [[narrative]]s in [[clinical practice]], research, and education as a way to promote healing. It aims to address the relational and psychological dimensions that occur in tandem with physical illness, with the attempt to treat patients as humans with individual stories, rather than purely based on symptoms.{{Cite web | url = http://www.law.nyu.edu/experientiallearninglab/methods/narrativemedicine/ | title = Narrative Medicine {{!}} NYU School of Law | website = www.law.nyu.edu | access-date = 2016-03-01 }} In doing this, narrative medicine aims not only to validate the experience of the patient, but also to encourage creativity and self-reflection in the physician. ==History== In 1910, the Carnegie Foundation for the Advancement of Teaching created Flexner's report, which set out to redefine medical educational practices. In this report, it argued that the proper goal of medicine is "to attempt to fight the battle against disease."{{Cite journal|last=Flexner|first=|date=1910|title=Medical Education in the United States and Canada|url=|journal=Carnegie Foundation for the Advancement of Teaching.|doi=|pmid=}} Towards the late 20th century, critics alleged that [[Western medicine]] had fallen victim to the professionalism movement. They argued that many [[medical schools]] and residency programs train physicians to treat medical problems purely on their symptoms without taking into account the specific psychological and personal history of the patient. The emergence of narrative medicine came as a contemporary effort to rehumanize medicine. One prominent medical school that first began a program on narrative medicine was [[Columbia University Medical Center]] with their opening of the first Program in Narrative Medicine. Built within their College of Physicians and Surgeons, they believe that narrative medicine can make profound changes to the way medical treatment is administered: “Narrative Medicine fortifies clinical practice with the narrative competence to recognize, absorb, metabolize, interpret, and be moved by the stories of illness. Through narrative training, the Program in Narrative Medicine helps physicians, nurses, social workers, mental health professionals, chaplains, social workers, academics, and all those interested in the intersection between narrative and medicine improve the effectiveness of care by developing these skills with patients and colleagues. Our research and outreach missions are conceptualizing, evaluating, and spear-heading these ideas and practices nationally and internationally."{{Cite web | url = http://www.narrativemedicine.org/leadership.html | title = Columbia University Medical Center {{!}} Program in Narrative Medicine | website = www.narrativemedicine.org | access-date = 2016-03-01 }} [[Rita Charon]] {{Cite web | url = http://www.narrativemedicine.org/leadership.html | title = Columbia University Medical Center {{!}} Program in Narrative Medicine | website = www.narrativemedicine.org | access-date = 2016-03-01 }} is the executive director of this program and has published and lectured on the benefits of doctors receiving narrative training as a way to increase empathy and reflection in the medical professional field. As of the late 1990s, physicians like [[Rachel Naomi Remen]] and [[Rita Charon]] have argued that medical practice should be structured around the narratives of patients. Charon stated:
"Sick people need physicians who can understand their diseases, treat their medical problems, and accompany them through their illnesses."{{Cite journal | doi = 10.1001/jama.286.15.1897 | issn = 0098-7484 | volume = 286 | issue = 15 | pages = 1897–1902 | last = Charon R | title = Narrative medicine: A model for empathy, reflection, profession, and trust | journal = JAMA: The Journal of the American Medical Association | accessdate = 2012-11-24 | date = 2001-10-17 | url = https://dx.doi.org/10.1001/jama.286.15.1897 }}
==Educational Programs== The number of schools in the United States that offer advanced classes in narrative medicine has been growing. * The [[Columbia University Medical Center]] has been the leading pioneer of developing educational programs for the field of narrative medicine. In addition to lectures and seminars given throughout the year, Columbia University created the Master of Science in Narrative Medicine program for graduate students in 2009, making it one of the first graduate programs devoted strictly to narrative medicine.[https://www.nytimes.com/2010/01/03/education/edlife/03narrative.html "Learning to Listen"] New York Times (2009-12-29) * [[Montefiore Medical Center]] is the academic medical center and University Hospital for [[Albert Einstein College of Medicine]]. This medical center created a program in Narrative Medicine as a subset of the Department of Family and Social Medicine. Residents at this school attend programs where they learn how to use personal narrative to enhance empathy, as well as topics including stress, loss, and balance. * The [[Ohio State University]] Humanities Institute is also supporting the multidisciplinary initiative of narrative medicine. This program runs concurrently with their other undergraduate and graduate programs, where students "strive to develop narrative competence that enables them to deliver care that is not only more empathetic and compassionate, but also more effective." * The [[University of California, Irvine|University of California Irvine]] College of Medicine has created an Integrative Medicine Program within the Department of Family Medicine. This program "strives to change the focus of healthcare and medical education for our residents, medical students and faculty to include a multidisciplinary, patient-centered approach that emphasizes wellness, prevention, and self-care skills, and the adoption of the principles for creating optimal healing environments."{{Cite web | url = http://www.familymed.uci.edu/residency/Integrative_Medicine.asp | title = Integrative Medicine Program {{!}} Department of Family Medicine {{!}} University of California, Irvine | website = www.familymed.uci.edu | access-date = 2016-03-01 }} * In 2011, Western University created the Narrative Medicine Initiative (NMI) and has incorporated narrative medicine into the undergraduate, postgraduate, and continuing medical education departments. They work to answer questions such as "How does the art of storytelling improve health care education and the experience of patient care?" * Lenoir-Rhyne University has established the Thomas Wolfe Center for Narrative, with the slogan "Heeding the call for narrative in a fragmented world." This program offers graduate-level and certification courses in several narrative training disciplines, one of which is narrative medicine. * Saybrook University takes a broad approach to narrative medicine through their mind-body medicine program. This seeks to approve the mind-body approach to health and wellness as a way to improve quality of life for patients. This growing field of narrative medicine extends beyond the United States: The British Medical Journal have begun adding their own writing seminars to promote this type of narrative in its emerging physicians. ==Obstacles== Rachel Remen asserts,
People who are physicians have been trained to believe that it is a scientific objectivity that makes them most effective in their efforts to understand and resolve the pain that others bring them, and a mental distance that protects them from becoming wounded from this difficult work.{{Cite book | publisher = Riverhead Books | isbn = 9781594482090 | last = Remen | first = Rachel Naomi | title = Kitchen Table Wisdom: Stories That Heal | date = 2006-08-01 }}
Objectivity, empathy, and global thinking are stated to not be incompatible with a degree of dissociation from the patient's suffering that is sufficient to protect oneself. ==See also== *[[Slow medicine]] ==References== {{Reflist}} ==Additional sources== *''Coyote Healing: Miracles in Native Medicine''. [[Lewis Mehl-Madrona]] M.D. Ph.D. [[Bear & Company]] (2003) {{ISBN|1-59143-010-0}} {{ISBN|978-1591430100}} ==External links== * http://www.utne.com/Spirituality/Narrative-Medicine-Heals-Bodies-and-Souls.aspx * https://www.npr.org/templates/story/story.php?storyId=1480863 __NEWSECTIONLINK__ {{DEFAULTSORT:Narrative Medicine}} [[Category:Medical humanities|Medical humanities]] [[Category:Medical terminology]] [[Category:Medical education]]

The '''National Council of Labour Colleges''' ('''NCLC''') was an organisation set up in the [[United Kingdom]] to foster [[working class]] self-education.
The organisation was founded in 1921 as a co-ordinating body for the movement of labour colleges,<ref name="jarvis">Peter Jarvis, ''An International Dictionary of Adult and Continuing Education'', pp.139, 218</ref> including the [[Central Labour College]].
The National Council of Labour Colleges absorbed the [[Plebs League]] the year after the [[1926 United Kingdom general strike]], and continued to publish the ''Plebs' Magazine''.<ref name="barberis">''Encyclopedia of British and Irish Political Organizations'', Peter Barberis, John McHugh and Mike Tyldesley (2000) p157</ref>
In 1964, the NCLC merged with the Workers' Educational Trade Union Committee to form the [[Trades Union Congress]] Education Department.<ref name="jarvis" />

{{refimprove|date=March 2014}} '''Natural religion''' most frequently means the "religion of nature", in which God, the soul, spirits, and all objects of the supernatural are considered as part of [[nature]] and not separate from it. Conversely, it is also used in [[philosophy]], specifically Roman Catholic philosophy, to describe some aspects of religion that are said to be knowable apart from divine revelation through logic and reason alone (see [[natural theology]] and [[Deism]]), for example, the existence of the [[God|unmoved Mover]], the [[first cause]] of the universe.
Most authors{{who|date=September 2018}} consider natural religion as not only the foundation of monotheistic religions such as Judaism, Christianity, and Islam but also distinct from them. According to some authors{{who|date=September 2018}}, aspects of natural religion are found universally among all peoples, often in such forms of [[shamanism]] and [[animism]]. They are still practiced in many parts of the world. The religions of [[Indigenous peoples of the Americas|Native American]] societies for example are considered as possessing some aspects of natural religion.
==Definition==
Natural religion might have the following meanings:
* In the modern [[Religious studies|study of religion]] it is used to refer to the notion that there is a spontaneous religious apprehension of the world common to all human beings, see: **[[urreligion]] **[[origin of religion]] **[[anthropology of religion]] * As a reverent form of [[nature worship]], embodied in a statement by [[Frank Lloyd Wright]]: "I put a capital N on Nature, and call it my Church."<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.hrc.utexas.edu/multimedia/video/2008/wallace/wright_frank_lloyd_t.html |title=Frank Lloyd Wright |publisher=[[The Mike Wallace Interview]] |year=1957 |website=[[Harry Ransom Center]]}}</ref> * Referring to the religions of people prior to their [[Christianization]].
==History==
The basic tenets of natural religion were outlined by [[Aristotle]], whose ''hylomorphism'' considered all things as made of matter and form. The form of all living things is the [[soul]], which guides and directs their development. Many natural religions{{which|date=September 2018}} consider God as the "soul of the universe".
Early [[monotheism]] had many naturalistic elements. Heaven and hell were considered physical places above and below the earth. "Salvation" was considered resurrection of the body.
In the fourth century, Christians were concerned that Jesus had not returned and wondered what happened to those who died before the Second Coming of Christ. Christians, led by [[Augustine of Hippo]] and under the influence of both [[gnosticism]] and [[neoplatonism]], developed a new belief in the soul as capable of a separate existence abstract from the material world. The human souls, unlike those of animals, would survive death and, depending on God's judgment, be transferred to the non-material realms of heaven or hell and the new realm of [[limbo]] for unbaptized persons and [[purgatory]] for those who do not deserve hell but are not purified for heaven..
Another distinction from monotheism is found in the Christian belief in miracles, in which God intervenes in history from outside nature. Ancient Roman philosophers and others since objected to this Christian doctrine as God violating his own natural laws. Christians had to separate God more completely from the natural universe in order to show how this could be possible. There were similar neoplatonist tendencies in Judaism and Islam, which also saw God as acting in history.
Natural religions, on the contrary, consider the supernatural as part of the natural universe.
==Modern views== One of the first attempts to develop a science of religion was ''[[The Varieties of Religious Experience]]'' by the American philosopher [[William James]]. James saw the basic experience which unified all religions as a sometimes life-changing personal event in which one perceives the connectedness of all things as one unified whole.
James defined the basics of all religion, including natural religion, when he wrote: "Were one to characterize the life of religion in the broadest and most general terms possible, one might say that it exists of the belief that there is an unseen order, and that our supreme good lies in harmoniously adjusting ourselves hereto."
Certain aspects of natural religion (that is, religious truths that are knowable by human reason alone) are found among different cultures, though not always entirely intact, and to varying degrees, according to philosophers such as [[Thomas Aquinas]] and [[Nicolas Malebranche|Malebranche]].
A few modern scientists such as UK biologist [[Rupert Sheldrake]] believe new discoveries coincide with Aristotle's belief in the soul. Forces such as [[magnetism]], [[gravity]], and [[quantum mechanics]] also point to non-material forces acting in nature.<ref>2012. Sheldrake, R. '''Set Science Free: 10 Paths to New Discoveries.''' Depak Chopra.</ref>
==See also== *[[Natural theology]], often synonymous in the 18th and 19th centuries— see, for example, [[David Hume]]'s ''[[Dialogues Concerning Natural Religion]]''. *[[Nature religion]] *[[Original monotheism]] *[[Perennial philosophy]] *[[Rational mysticism]] *[[Spiritual but not religious]] *[[Naturalistic spirituality]]

revision.comment: [[Wikipedia:OABOT|Open access bot]]: add pmc identifier to citation with #oabot.
revision.text:
'''Nutrient cycling in the Columbia River Basin''' involves the transport of nutrients through the system, as well as transformations from among dissolved, solid, and gaseous phases, depending on the element. The elements that constitute important [[nutrient cycle]]s include [[macronutrients]] such as [[nitrogen|nitrogen (as ammonium, nitrite, and nitrate)]], [[silicate]], [[phosphorus]], and [[micronutrient]]s, which are found in trace amounts, such as [[iron]]. Their [[Nutrient cycle|cycling]] within a system is controlled by many biological, chemical, and physical processes.
The [[Columbia River Drainage Basin|Columbia River Basin]] is the largest freshwater system of the [[Pacific Northwest]], and due to its complexity, size, and modification by humans, nutrient cycling within the system is affected by many different components. Both natural and [[Human impact on the environment|anthropogenic]] processes are involved in the cycling of nutrients. Natural processes in the system include [[Estuary|estuarine]] mixing of fresh and ocean waters, and [[climate]] variability patterns such as the [[Pacific Decadal Oscillation]] and the [[El Niño–Southern Oscillation|El Nino Southern Oscillation]] (both climatic cycles that affect the amount of regional snowpack and river discharge).<ref name=":2">{{Cite web|url=http://www.ecy.wa.gov/programs/eap/Nitrogen/FateTransport.html|title=Fate and Transport of Nitrogen {{!}} Environmental Assessment Program {{!}} Washington State Department of Ecology, Puget Sound|website=www.ecy.wa.gov|access-date=2017-11-07|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20171208003427/http://www.ecy.wa.gov/programs/eap/Nitrogen/FateTransport.html|archivedate=2017-12-08|df=}}</ref><ref>{{Cite journal|last=Hamlet|first=Alan F.|last2=Lettenmaier|first2=Dennis P.|date=1999-11-01|title=Columbia River Streamflow Forecasting Based on ENSO and PDO Climate Signals|url=http://ascelibrary.org/doi/10.1061/%28ASCE%290733-9496%281999%29125%3A6%28333%29|journal=Journal of Water Resources Planning and Management|volume=125|issue=6|pages=333–341|doi=10.1061/(ASCE)0733-9496(1999)125:6(333)|via=}}</ref> Natural sources of nutrients in the [[Columbia River]] include [[weathering]], leaf litter, [[salmon]] carcasses, runoff from its [[Tributary|tributaries]], and [[Estuarine water circulation|ocean estuary exchange]]. Major anthropogenic impacts to nutrients in the basin are due to [[fertilizer]]s from agriculture, [[sewage]] systems, [[logging]], and the construction of [[dam]]s.<ref name=":12">{{Cite web|url=http://www.ecy.wa.gov/programs/eap/Nitrogen/NitrogenNaturalSources.html|title=Natural Sources of Nitrogen {{!}} Sources and Pathways {{!}} Environmental Assessment Program {{!}} Washington State Department of Ecology|website=www.ecy.wa.gov|access-date=2017-11-04|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20171208003233/http://www.ecy.wa.gov/programs/eap/Nitrogen/NitrogenNaturalSources.html|archivedate=2017-12-08|df=}}</ref><ref name=":1">{{Cite journal|last=Hileman|first=James|date=July 1975|title=Columbia River Nutrient Study|url=|journal=Environmental Protection Agency|volume=|pages=|via=}}</ref>
Nutrients dynamics vary in the river basin from the [[River source|headwaters]] to the main river and dams, to finally reaching the [[Columbia River Estuary|Columbia River estuary]] and ocean. Upstream in the headwaters, [[salmon run]]s are the main source of nutrients.<ref name=":13">{{Cite news|url=https://www.wildsalmoncenter.org/work/why-protect-salmon/|title=Why Protect Salmon - Wild Salmon Center|work=Wild Salmon Center|access-date=2017-11-27|language=en-US}}</ref> Dams along the river impact nutrient cycling by increasing [[Residence time (fluid dynamics)|residence time]] of nutrients, and reducing the transport of [[silicate]] to the estuary, which directly impacts [[diatom]]s, a type of [[phytoplankton]].<ref name=":9">{{Cite journal|last=Friedl|first=Gabriela|last2=Wüest|first2=Alfred|date=2002-04-01|title=Disrupting biogeochemical cycles - Consequences of damming|url=https://link.springer.com/article/10.1007/s00027-002-8054-0|journal=Aquatic Sciences|language=en|volume=64|issue=1|pages=55–65|doi=10.1007/s00027-002-8054-0|issn=1015-1621}}</ref> The dams are also a barrier to salmon migration, and can increase the amount of [[methane]] locally produced.<ref name=":9" /> The Columbia River estuary exports high rates of nutrients into the [[Pacific Ocean]];<ref name=":15">{{Cite journal|last=Gilbert|first=Melissa|last2=Needoba|first2=Joseph|last3=Koch|first3=Corey|last4=Barnard|first4=Andrew|last5=Baptista|first5=Antonio|date=2013-07-01|title=Nutrient Loading and Transformations in the Columbia River Estuary Determined by High-Resolution In Situ Sensors|url=https://link.springer.com/article/10.1007/s12237-013-9597-0|journal=Estuaries and Coasts|language=en|volume=36|issue=4|pages=708–727|doi=10.1007/s12237-013-9597-0|issn=1559-2723}}</ref> with the exception of nitrogen, which is delivered into the estuary by ocean [[upwelling]] sources.<ref name=":6">{{Cite journal|last=Lohan|first=Maeve C.|last2=Bruland|first2=Kenneth W.|date=2006-02-01|title=Importance of vertical mixing for additional sources of nitrate and iron to surface waters of the Columbia River plume: Implications for biology|url=http://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S0304420305001428|journal=Marine Chemistry|volume=98|issue=2|pages=260–273|doi=10.1016/j.marchem.2005.10.003}}</ref>
== Description == [[File:Columbiarivermap.png|thumb|Map of the [[Columbia River Drainage Basin|Columbia Basin]]]] The [[Columbia River]] basin is a major watershed and the largest river in the Pacific Northwest region of [[North America]]. Extending from southern [[British Columbia]] to northern [[Nevada]], the watershed includes seven American states and two Canadian provinces and drains an area of about 260,000 square miles.<ref name=":0">{{Cite web|url=http://www.ecy.wa.gov/programs/wr/cwp/cwpfactmap.html|title=Columbia River Facts and Maps|website=www.ecy.wa.gov|access-date=2017-11-03}}</ref><ref name=":3">{{Cite journal|last=Naik|first=Pradeep K.|last2=Jay|first2=David A.|date=July 2011|title=Distinguishing human and climate influences on the Columbia River: Changes in mean flow and sediment transport|url=http://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S0022169411002964|journal=Journal of Hydrology|volume=404|issue=3-4|pages=259–277|doi=10.1016/j.jhydrol.2011.04.035|via=Elsevier Science Direct}}</ref> The Columbia River stretches 1,620 miles in length until its discharge into the Pacific Ocean near [[Astoria, Oregon]].<ref name=":10">{{Cite web|url=https://pubs.usgs.gov/sir/2007/5186/section3.html|title=Nutrient and Suspended-Sediment Transport and Trends in the Columbia River and Puget Sound Basins, 1993–2003|last=Sobieszczyk|first=By Daniel R. Wise, Frank A. Rinella III, Joseph F. Rinella, Greg J. Fuhrer, Sandra S. Embrey, Gregory M. Clark, Gregory E. Schwarz, and Steven|date=|website=pubs.usgs.gov|language=en|access-date=2017-11-20}}</ref> The average annual [[Discharge (hydrology)|discharge]] rate of the Columbia River changes due to climate and land-use variability, but generally ranges from 120,000 to 260,000 cubic feet per second.<ref name=":0" /> Finally, the population of the Columbia River Basin within the United States is about 4.6 million people (per the 2000 census).<ref name=":10" />
The water cycle in the Columbia River is dependent on the relation between water flow and topography in the basin. Within the United States, only the [[Mississippi River System|Missouri-Mississippi]] River system has annual runoff greater than that of the Columbia River.<ref name=":10" /> The amount of water that the river carries each year is determined by the precipitation, sunlight, and air temperature in the basin, which varies from year to year.<ref name=":10" /> West of the [[Cascade Range]], most of the winter precipitation falls as rain, but in the Cascade Mountains and eastward, precipitation through winter is snow. [[Snowmelt]] in the mountains begins to reach the river during early to mid-spring. About 30 percent of the streamflow in the Columbia River occurs between January and March (primarily from rainfall) and about 30 percent occurs between April and June (from a combination of rainfall and snowmelt).<ref name=":10" />
== Natural processes == [[Upwelling|Coastal upwelling]], [[discharge (hydrology)|river discharge]], [[Tide|tidal]] mixing, [[Estuarine water circulation|estuarine circulation]], [[climate oscillation]], and [[Remineralisation|remineralization]], are sources or sinks for the Columbia River basin nutrient budget.<ref name=":4">{{cite journal|last1=Whitney|first1=F. A.|last2=Crawford|first2=W. R.|last3=Harrison|first3=P. J.|date=1 March 2005|title=Physical processes that enhance nutrient transport and primary productivity in the coastal and open ocean of the subarctic NE Pacific|url=https://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S0967064505000044|journal=Deep Sea Research Part II: Topical Studies in Oceanography|volume=52|issue=5|pages=681–706|doi=10.1016/j.dsr2.2004.12.023|accessdate=7 November 2017}}</ref> Due to these transport processes the [[Columbia River Estuary]] provides large nutrient sources to the adjacent sub-arctic Northeast Pacific coastal surface water.<ref name=":4" />
Nitrogen is added to rivers through many natural processes, such as the decomposition of leaf litter and organic matter. Nitrogen gas is the most abundant molecule in earth's atmosphere, comprising about 78 percent of the total composition of air,<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://tornado.sfsu.edu/geosciences/classes/m201/Atmosphere/AtmosphericComposition.html|title=Atmospheric Composition|website=tornado.sfsu.edu|access-date=2017-11-04}}</ref> however not typically a large source of nitrogen to the river. This form of nitrogen, dinitrogen gas (<chem>N2</chem>), is inert and biologically unavailable to most living organisms. However, some [[bacteria]] and [[archaea]] can utilize [[nitrogen fixation]] to convert dinitrogen into ammonia or other compounds accessible to organisms.
Finally, nitrogen load at the Columbia River mouth is about 2-20 times larger than that at the Canadian border.<ref name=":1" /> This gradient in nitrogen distribution is partly a result of the inputs of the Columbia's major tributaries, the [[Snake River]] and the [[Willamette River]]. The Snake and Willamette rivers together contribute about 50-80 percent of the nitrogen load in a given year, coming from activities within those respective watersheds.<ref name=":1" />
=== Weathering and runoff === [[Weathering]] is the break down of rocks, soil, and minerals through contact with water, the atmosphere, and biological organisms, converting solid phase minerals to dissolved phase compounds. This process can introduce nutrients, most notably phosphorus, into the Columbia watershed.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Wise|first=Daniel R.|last2=Johnson|first2=Henry M.|date=2011-10-01|title=Surface-Water Nutrient Conditions and Sources in the United States Pacific Northwest1|url=http://onlinelibrary.wiley.com/doi/10.1111/j.1752-1688.2011.00580.x/abstract|journal=JAWRA Journal of the American Water Resources Association|language=en|volume=47|issue=5|pages=1110–1135|doi=10.1111/j.1752-1688.2011.00580.x|issn=1752-1688|pmc=3307616}}</ref> Both [[Weathering|chemical]] and [[Weathering|physical weathering]] occur, usually together, and this coupling tends to accelerate the other. Precipitation varies across the basin, influencing the amount of weathering and subsequent runoff that transports this material into the basin.
Organic matter such as leaves may also naturally fall into the waterways through runoff. Over time, this material is [[Cellular respiration|respired]], releasing assimilated nutrients into the environment.
=== Salmon impacts on nutrient cycling === An important source of nutrients, such as [[Nitrogen cycle|nitrogen]] and [[Phosphorus cycle|phosphorus]], for rivers in the Pacific Northwest is the [[spawning]] of salmon and subsequent death and decomposition of fish up-river. Every fall, ocean salmon at the end of their life cycle swim upriver to spawn before they die. The [[Remineralisation|remineralization]] of their organic matter releases significant nitrogen loads into the river, although recent decades have observed decreased salmon runs and subsequently less impact on the total nitrogen budget.<ref name=":12" />
Salmon are an [[anadromous]] family of fish that rear in freshwater, migrate to the ocean as juveniles, and then return to the freshwater as adults to lay their eggs and die in what is called a [[salmon run]]. Their death and subsequent [[decomposition]] releases substantial amounts of nitrogen and lower amounts of phosphorus into the system, boosting the [[Primary production|productivity]] of local headwaters and serving as a vector of material transport across the ocean to [[Drainage basin|watershed]] interface.<ref name=":13" /> Studies have estimated salmon in some parts of the Columbia river contribute up to 60 percent of nitrogen to other [[trophic level]]s.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Cederholm|first=C. Jeff|last2=Kunze|first2=Matt D.|last3=Murota|first3=Takeshi|last4=Sibatani|first4=Atuhiro|date=1999-10-01|title=Pacific Salmon Carcasses: Essential Contributions of Nutrients and Energy for Aquatic and Terrestrial Ecosystems|url=https://doi.org/10.1577/1548-8446(1999)0242.0.CO;2|journal=Fisheries|volume=24|issue=10|pages=6–15|doi=10.1577/1548-8446(1999)0242.0.CO;2|issn=0363-2415}}</ref>
The regional ubiquity of salmon as a recreational and commercial [[fishery]] has led to increased attention on local populations within the Columbia River system. Annual [[Salmon-fishing|salmon harvests]] are among the highest-earners of the Pacific Northwest fishery economy; in the lower Columbia River specifically, salmon account for over 84 percent of commercial fish landings.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=|first=|date=December 2008|title=Economic Analysis of the Non-Treaty Commercial and Recreational Fisheries in Washington State|url=http://wdfw.wa.gov/publications/00464/wdfw00464.pdf|journal=Washington Department of Fish and Wildlife|volume=|pages=|via=}}</ref>
While areas accessible to salmon have been reduced over the past century through the construction of dams and the modification of river channels, this group of fish historically inhabited almost 13,000 miles of the Columbia River basin. <ref name=":11">{{Cite news|url=http://www.critfc.org/fish-and-watersheds/columbia-river-fish-species/columbia-river-salmon/|title=Columbia River Salmon, Pacific Northwest {{!}} Chinook Salmon|work=CRITFC|access-date=2017-11-27|language=en-US}}</ref> Efforts from [[Fisheries management|fishery management]] and state agencies, as well as the listing of several resident salmon stocks under the protection of the [[Endangered Species Act of 1973|Endangered Species Act]], has led to the re-establishment of accessibility to some parts of the Columbia River system for salmon.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.westcoast.fisheries.noaa.gov/stories/2013/08_2013_07_11_lower_columbia_recovery_plan_adopted.html|title=Newly adopted Recovery Plan guides restoration of lower Columbia River salmon & steelhead|last=Fisheries|first=NOAA|date=Summer 2013|website=www.westcoast.fisheries.noaa.gov|language=en-us|access-date=2017-12-04}}</ref> The regional return of salmon runs restores an important segment of local nutrient cycles, particularly that of nitrogen and phosphorus, to the system.
=== Estuarine and ocean exchange === The [[Columbia River Estuary]] is the most downstream portion of the river that experiences ocean tides, generally defined as the furthest reach of the Columbia River plume to the [[Bonneville Dam]].<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://water.usgs.gov/GIS/metadata/usgswrd/XML/creec_geomorphic_catena.xml|title=Columbia River Estuary Ecosystem Classification Geomorphic Catena|website=water.usgs.gov|access-date=2017-12-04}}</ref> Here, a transition zone occurs where freshwater discharge from the river meets and mixes with Pacific Ocean saltwater. In this region, physical processes that affect nutrients are the [[Ocean circulation|circulation]] (entrance/exit, movement) of specific water masses with their nutrient load, the magnitude of tidal flow distributing ocean waters inland, and bottom sediment exchange affecting nutrient particle mobility.<ref name=":2" />
With the exception of nitrogen, the Columbia River estuary nutrient budget tends to be dominated by nutrient transport out of the system.<ref name=":15" /> During periods of high river flow, generally April to June, the estuary has a daily average residence time of less than a day.<ref name=":17">{{Cite journal|last=Kärnä|first=Tuomas|last2=Baptista|first2=António M.|title=Water age in the Columbia River estuary|url=https://doi.org/10.1016/j.ecss.2016.09.001|journal=Estuarine, Coastal and Shelf Science|volume=183|pages=249–259|doi=10.1016/j.ecss.2016.09.001}}</ref> Meanwhile, at times of lowest river discharge, typically September to October, this [[turnover time]] lengthens to about three days.<ref name=":17" /> The turnover time can also vary due to the tidal cycle, and affect the amount of oceanic exchange in the estuary; on the whole the residence time is fairly short. Through a more rapid transit time of waters within the river, local [[primary production]] tends to be lower as [[autotroph]]ic communities are quickly flushed out of the system.<ref name=":15" /> Since there is less subsequent biological uptake of nutrients, there is a high rate of nutrient transport out of the Columbia River and into coastal waters.<ref name=":15" />
The upwelled waters of the Pacific Ocean have very high concentrations of dissolved nutrients due to the history of [[Cellular respiration|biological respiration]] that has occurred throughout the water masses' time in circulation through the deep ocean.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Hickey|first=Barbara|last2=Banas|first2=Neil|date=2003|title=Oceanography of the U.S. Pacific Northwest Coastal Ocean and estuaries with application to coastal ecology|url=|journal=Estuaries|volume=26|issue=4|pages=|via=}}</ref> Biological [[Cellular respiration|respiration]] is the consumption of organic matter and concurrent release of nutrients contained in that biomass. This process is an important source for nutrients that other organisms require. Examples of these organisms include [[phytoplankton]] and [[algae]], whose communities are often limited in growth by the availability of specific nutrients, most commonly nitrogen which is the primary limiting nutrient the Columbia River.<ref name=":15" /> In addition, to nitrogen, iron, and silicate cycling in the estuary can impact local and coastal ocean phytoplankton communities.
==== Nitrate ==== Due to coastal upwelling, ocean sources of [[nitrate]] (an oxidized form of nitrogen) exceed river sources by a magnitude of roughly 3 to 1, and is a primary source of nitrogen for the Columbia River Estuary.<ref name=":6" /> This is evident within the estuary by the positively correlated relationship of nitrate availability and salinity, the latter an identifying characteristic of highly saline marine waters.<ref name=":7">{{Cite journal|last=Haertel|first=Lois|last2=Osterberg|first2=Charles|last3=Curl|first3=Herbert|last4=Park|first4=P. Kilho|date=1969-11-01|title=Nutrient and Plankton Ecology of the Columbia River Estuary|url=http://onlinelibrary.wiley.com/doi/10.2307/1936889/abstract|journal=Ecology|language=en|volume=50|issue=6|pages=962–978|doi=10.2307/1936889|issn=1939-9170}}</ref> As a result of differences in delivery to the system, nitrate is the primary limiting nutrient in the estuary.<ref name=":15" /> Consequently, during seasonal periods of downwelling when less ocean water is mixed into the estuary, local nitrate concentrations may be very low.<ref name=":6" /><ref name=":7" /> Thus, [[Nutrient cycle|nutrient cycling]] and [[primary production]] in the estuary are heavily linked with the seasonal winds off the Oregon and Washington coasts that control local ocean upwelling and downwelling.<ref name=":8">{{Cite journal|last=Roegner|first=G. Curtis|last2=Needoba|first2=Joseph A.|last3=Baptista|first3=António M.|date=2011-04-20|title=Coastal Upwelling Supplies Oxygen-Depleted Water to the Columbia River Estuary|url=http://journals.plos.org/plosone/article?id=10.1371/journal.pone.0018672|journal=PLOS ONE|volume=6|issue=4|pages=e18672|doi=10.1371/journal.pone.0018672|issn=1932-6203}}</ref>
==== Phosphate ==== Although phosphorus is of interest in the mid-river, especially in and around reservoirs throughout the Columbia River Basin as discussed below, it is not typically a [[limiting nutrient]] for biological communities within the estuary.<ref name=":5">{{Cite journal|last=LARA-LARA 1, FREY 2, SMALL 3|first=J. RUBEN 1, BRUCE E.2, LAWRENCE F. 3|date=1990|title=Primary Production in the Columbia River Estuary I. Spatial and Temporal Variability of Properties|url=http://scholarspace.manoa.hawaii.edu/bitstream/10125/1240/1/v44n1-17-37.pdf|journal=Pacific Science|volume=44|pages=17–37|via=}}</ref> As a result, there is little available literature on phosphate cycling within the estuary. [[File:Corps-engineers-archives bonneville dam looking east.jpg|thumb|452x452px|Aerial view of Columbia River and Bonneville Dam]]
==== Iron ==== The primary source of [[iron]] into the estuary is from geologic rock [[weathering]] and subsequent runoff delivery to the system. In addition, some iron may come from the Pacific Ocean and is transported into the estuary during tidal oscillation, enhanced seasonally during periods of upwelling.<ref name=":6" /> Iron inputs derived from riverine and oceanic origins are typically on the magnitude of 14-30 nM and 6 nM in concentration respectively.<ref name=":6" /> These sources of iron are generally sufficient to meet biological demands, including those of primary production, in the estuary and upriver. Consequently, iron is commonly not the limiting nutrient in the system; rather, the river depending on season and flow may serve as a net source of iron to iron-deficient coastal regions of the Northeast Pacific, sometimes referred to as areas of [[High-Nutrient, low-chlorophyll|High Nutrient, Low Chlorophyll]].<ref name=":6" /><ref>{{Cite journal|last=Martin|first=John H.|last2=Fitzwater|first2=Steve E.|date=1988-01-28|title=Iron deficiency limits phytoplankton growth in the north-east Pacific subarctic|url=https://www.nature.com/articles/331341a0|journal=Nature|language=en|volume=331|issue=6154|pages=341–343|doi=10.1038/331341a0|issn=1476-4687}}</ref><ref>{{Cite journal|last=Martin|first=John H.|last2=Michael Gordon|first2=R.|date=1988-02-01|title=Northeast Pacific iron distributions in relation to phytoplankton productivity|url=http://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/0198014988900350|journal=Deep Sea Research Part A. Oceanographic Research Papers|volume=35|issue=2|pages=177–196|doi=10.1016/0198-0149(88)90035-0}}</ref>
==== Silicate ==== As discussed in more detail below, dams can cause large scale [[hydrological]] changes by forming [[reservoir]]s. These reservoirs can act as nutrient traps altering nutrient ratios and reducing silicate transport through rivers and into the estuary.<ref name=":16">{{Cite journal|last=Venugopalan|first=Ittekkot,|last2=Christoph|first2=Humborg,|last3=Petra|first3=Schäfer,|date=2000-09-01|title=Hydrological Alterations and Marine Biogeochemistry: A Silicate Issue?Silicate retention in reservoirs behind dams affects ecosystem structure in coastal seas|url=https://academic.oup.com/bioscience/article/50/9/776/269450|journal=BioScience|language=en|volume=50|issue=9|doi=10.1641/0006-3568(2000)050[0776:HAAMBA]2.0.CO;2|issn=0006-3568}}</ref><ref name=":9" /> Since mid twentieth-century [[Columbia river dams|dam construction on the Columbia river]], seasonal silicate transport out of the Columbia River Estuary has shifted in magnitude since the historical, pre-alteration of the river hydrology.<ref name=":4" />
Outside the estuary, the Columbia river is a source of silicate for the [[Subarctic|sub-arctic]] Northeast Pacific coast.<ref name=":4" /> Silicate is a required nutrient for [[diatom]]s, which form [[siliceous]] <nowiki/>shells, within the surface waters of this coastal region.<ref name=":4" /><ref>{{Cite journal|last=Takeda|first=Shigenobu|date=1998-06-25|title=Influence of iron availability on nutrient consumption ratio of diatoms in oceanic waters|url=https://www.nature.com/nature/journal/v393/n6687/abs/393774a0.html|journal=Nature|language=en|volume=393|issue=6687|pages=774–777|doi=10.1038/31674|issn=0028-0836}}</ref><ref>{{Cite journal|last=Wong|first=C. S|last2=Matear|first2=R. J|date=1999-11-01|title=Sporadic silicate limitation of phytoplankton productivity in the subarctic NE Pacific|url=http://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S0967064599000752|journal=Deep Sea Research Part II: Topical Studies in Oceanography|volume=46|issue=11|pages=2539–2555|doi=10.1016/S0967-0645(99)00075-2}}</ref> The observed shift in silicate transport out of the Columbia River estuary since 1970 has resulted in the development of seasonal silicate limited regions of diatom production in coastal waters near the estuary.<ref name=":4" /><ref name=":16" /><ref name=":5" />
=== PDO and ENSO === [[Nutrient cycle|Nutrient dynamics]] are also affected on a long-term scale by human and climate influences.<ref name=":3" /> Specifically, the Columbia River discharge rates, which govern bulk nutrient transport, follow [[Pacific decadal oscillation|Pacific Decadal Oscillation]] (PDO) and [[El Niño–Southern Oscillation|El Niño Southern Oscillation]] (ENSO). This is because of how these oscillations affect regional air temperature, [[precipitation]] patterns, and off shore wind, which in turn affect annual [[snowpack]], [[sea surface temperature]]s, and [[upwelling]] and [[downwelling]] trends. Changes in these trends can alter the magnitude of [[Runoff (hydrology)|runoff]] from land incorporated into the Columbia River system as well as [[Estuarine water circulation|coastal ocean inflow]], which ultimately alter nutrient loading by either bringing in additional nutrients or washing them out.
Research indicates dam construction on the river has affected the strength of PDO and ENSO's influence through alteration of runoff residence times, but to date these effects have not been well described.<ref name=":3" /> Since 1858, total silicate transport has decreased by 50 percent, with 10 percent of that decrease directly linked to these climate oscillations.<ref name=":3" /> This alteration of net nutrient transport is critical to determining nutrient distribution and availability throughout the basin. Silicate, for example, may direct nutrient cycling by altering environmental parameters implicated in primary production by organisms, including river depth, flood frequency, and turbidity.<ref name=":3" /><ref name=":5" />
=== Greening of the estuary === It has been observed that the Columbia River estuary is "greening". "Greening" of the estuary describes the movement of [[phytoplankton]] [[Algal bloom|bloom]]s that historically occurred outside the mouth of the river, and are now blooming much more frequently inside the estuary, effectively "greening" the river surface with colored microscopic organisms.<ref name="Sullivan2000"/>
[[Primary production]] in this region is often dominated by [[diatom]] species such as ''Skeletomema costatum, Chaetoceros'' spp. and ''Thalassiosira'' spp. which bloom seasonally in spring and summer. Large blooms of these species consume the available nitrogen in the region, eventually hindering the furthering blooming by creating a nitrate-limited growth period.<ref name=":4" /> Exacerbating this nitrogen depletion, high estuarine turnover times in the Columbia River Estuary displace these diatoms communities out into the ocean. This export reduces rates of nitrogen [[Remineralisation|remineralization]] as the available nitrogen consumed by the diatom blooms is removed from the estuary system.<ref name=":4" />
The nitrogen-deplete conditions created by these blooms are improved as natural and [[Human impact on the environment|anthroprogenic]] [[Macro-Nutrients|macro-nutrients]] and [[Micronutrient|micro-nutrients]] are transported into the system by river discharge.<ref name=":4" /><ref>{{Cite journal|last=Meybeck|first=Michael|date=April 1982|title=Carbon, Nitrogen, and Phosphorus Transport by Worlds Rivers|url=http://earth.geology.yale.edu/~ajs/1982/04.1982.01.Maybeck.pdf|journal=American Journal of Science|volume=282|pages=401–450|via=}}</ref><ref>{{Cite journal|last=Whitney|first=F. A.|last2=Crawford|first2=W. R.|last3=Harrison|first3=P. J.|date=2005-03-01|title=Physical processes that enhance nutrient transport and primary productivity in the coastal and open ocean of the subarctic NE Pacific|url=http://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S0967064505000044|journal=Deep Sea Research Part II: Topical Studies in Oceanography|series=Linkages between coastal and open ocean ecosystems|volume=52|issue=5|pages=681–706|doi=10.1016/j.dsr2.2004.12.023}}</ref> The spring-summer [[seasonality]] of these diatom blooms is affected by climate, variable with both [[Pacific decadal oscillation|Pacific Decadal Oscillation]] (PDO) and [[El Niño–Southern Oscillation|El Niño Southern Oscillation]] (ENSO) indices, and human influences such as dam construction in the watershed.<ref name=":3" /> As discussed previously, both climate oscillation and human interaction in the Columbia watershed have been shown decrease transport of nutrients into the estuary.
As an example of human impacts on this system, the increased footprint of water reservoirs caused by damning of the Columbia River has resulted in a standing pools of nitrogen, carbon, and phosphorus.<ref name=":9" /> These nutrients mostly stay within the watershed during winter months instead of discharging to the ocean, as river discharge rates are controlled by dam release schedules.<ref name=":9" /> As a result, these nutrients and organic matter are locally biochemically processed by plankton communities, increasing the biomass of life within the system, and resulting in high nutrient releases in spring and summer months when dam flow through is increased.<ref name="Sullivan2000">{{Cite journal|last=Sullivan|first=B|date=2000|title=Seasonality of phytoplankton production in the Columbia River: A natural or anthropogenic pattern?|url=|journal=Geochimica et Cosmochimica Acta|volume=|pages=|via=}}</ref><ref name=":9" /> As a result, this [[Anthropogenic effect|anthroprogenic]] discharge cycle contributes to the seasonality of diatom blooms in the estuary.
Unlike other large estuaries, such as the [[Chesapeake Bay|Chesapeake Bay Estuary]], the Columbia River supplies little nitrate to the estuary relative to the overall local nitrogen budget. Rather, the primary source of nitrate into the estuary is from ocean exchange caused by wind-driven seasonal upwelling off the Oregon and Washington coasts.<ref name=":6" /> This influx of nitrate, generally the primary limiting nutrient to biological communities in the estuary, is an important driver of primary productivity in estuarine plumes of river discharge. Moreover, large scale upwelling on the Oregon-Washington coast typically occurs in spring and summer, and as discussed previously, is coupled with the PDO and ENSO, this seasonal upwelling further contributes to diatom bloom in the estuary.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://damp.coas.oregonstate.edu/windstress/|title=Wind stress, cumulative wind stress, and spring transition dates: data products for Oregon upwelling-related research|last=Pierce|first=S.D.|last2=Barth|first2=J. A.|date=2017|website=damp.coas.oregonstate.edu|publication-place=Oregon State University, College of Earth, Ocean, & Atmospheric Sciences|access-date=2017-12-05}}</ref><ref name=":3" /> Finally, without this source of nitrogen through upwelling, the estuary quickly becomes nitrate limited and hinders further facilitation of biological activity.<ref name=":6" /><ref name=":7" />
=== Red blooms === [[File:Red tide＿2017.jpg|thumb|320x320px|Red bloom in a harbor. The vibrant color of the blooms attracts attention from scientists and local community members.]] Red [[Algal bloom|blooms]], a type of [[plankton]] bloom with a characteristic scarlet pigment, occur every year in the Columbia River estuary, lasting several months during late summer to early fall.<ref name=":14">{{Cite journal|last=Herfort|first=Lydie|last2=Peterson|first2=Tawnya D.|last3=Prahl|first3=Fredrick G.|last4=McCue|first4=Lee Ann|last5=Needoba|first5=Joseph A.|last6=Crump|first6=Byron C.|last7=Roegner|first7=G. Curtis|last8=Campbell|first8=Victoria|last9=Zuber|first9=Peter|date=2012-05-01|title=Red Waters of Myrionecta rubra are Biogeochemical Hotspots for the Columbia River Estuary with Impacts on Primary/Secondary Productions and Nutrient Cycles|url=https://link.springer.com/article/10.1007/s12237-012-9485-z|journal=Estuaries and Coasts|language=en|volume=35|issue=3|pages=878–891|doi=10.1007/s12237-012-9485-z|issn=1559-2723}}</ref> The marine [[ciliate]] ''[[Myrionecta rubra]]'' is responsible for this annual discoloration. Research has found that while not toxic, dense blooms of ''M. rubra'' can impact estuaries, fjords, and upwelling areas and have been associated with high rates of local [[primary production]].<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Gustafson|first=Daniel E.|last2=Stoecker|first2=Diane K.|last3=Johnson|first3=Matthew D.|last4=Heukelem|first4=William F. Van|last5=Sneider|first5=Kerri|date=June 2000|title=Cryptophyte algae are robbed of their organelles by the marine ciliate Mesodinium rubrum|url=http://www.nature.com/articles/35016570|journal=Nature|language=En|volume=405|issue=6790|pages=1049–1052|doi=10.1038/35016570|issn=1476-4687|via=}}</ref><ref name=":14" />
''M. rubra'' gets its red color from consuming [[Cryptomonad|cryptophytes]], or algae, that contain a red pigment called [[phycoerythrin]] in their [[chloroplast]]s.<ref name=":21">{{Cite journal|last=Hansen|first=Per Juel|last2=Fenchel|first2=Tom|date=July 2006|title=The bloom-forming ciliate Mesodinium rubrum harbours a single permanent endosymbiont|url=https://doi.org/10.1080/17451000600719577|journal=Marine Biology Research|volume=2|issue=3|pages=169–177|doi=10.1080/17451000600719577|issn=1745-1000|via=}}</ref><ref name=":23">Sherry, Elisabeth J. (2015). "A Model of Mesodinium Rubrum Blooms in the Columbia River Estuary." (Doctoral dissertation).</ref>  In the Columbia River estuary, ''M. rubra'' commonly preys on the cryptophyte ''[[Geminigeraceae|Teleaulax amphioxeia]].''<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Peterson|first=TD|last2=Golda|first2=RL|last3=Garcia|first3=ML|last4=Li|first4=B|last5=Maier|first5=MA|last6=Needoba|first6=JA|last7=Zuber|first7=P|date=2013-01-29|title=Associations between Mesodinium rubrum and cryptophyte algae in the Columbia River estuary|url=https://doi.org/10.3354/ame01598|journal=Aquatic Microbial Ecology|language=en|volume=68|issue=2|pages=117–130|doi=10.3354/ame01598|issn=0948-3055}}</ref> From its prey, ''M. rubra'' also acquires specialty cellular [[Organelle|organs]] in order to photosynthesize and effectively absorbs these compounds into its own body. This process is referred to as "acquired [[phototroph]]y", and for ''M. rubra'' includes the assimilation of [[chloroplast]]s, [[Cell nucleus|nuclei]], and [[Mitochondrion|mitochondria]]<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Johnson|first=Matthew D.|last2=Oldach|first2=David|last3=Delwiche|first3=Charles F.|last4=Stoecker|first4=Diane K.|date=Jan 2007|title=Retention of transcriptionally active cryptophyte nuclei by the ciliate Myrionecta rubra|url=http://www.nature.com/articles/nature05496|journal=Nature|language=En|volume=445|issue=7126|pages=426–428|doi=10.1038/nature05496|issn=1476-4687|via=}}</ref><ref name=":22" /> During the day, the [[ciliate]]s stay near the surface of the water to [[Photosynthesis|photosynthesize]], which is how the red blooms are easily observed.<ref name=":23" />
One question of interest associated with ''M. rubra'' is its ability to spread within the Columbia River estuary in spite of the short residence time of the water. The red blooms have been observed initiating near the river mouth, then establishing throughout the entire lower estuary.<ref name=":22">{{Cite journal|last=Herfort|first=Lydie|last2=Peterson|first2=Tawnya D.|last3=Campbell|first3=Victoria|last4=Futrell|first4=Sheedra|last5=Zuber|first5=Peter|date=December 2011|title=Myrionecta rubra (Mesodinium rubrum) bloom initiation in the Columbia River estuary|url=https://doi.org/10.1016/j.ecss.2011.10.015|journal=Estuarine, Coastal and Shelf Science|language=en|volume=95|issue=4|pages=440–446|doi=10.1016/j.ecss.2011.10.015|via=}}</ref> ''M. rubra'' is quite motile and can swim (1.2 cm / second) and jump (as much as 160 µm in 20 milliseconds),<ref name=":21" /> which could explain how they are able to stay within the estuary for months at a time.  
The blooms have a dramatic impact on the local [[ecosystem]] and nutrient levels. Globally, studies have shown that ''M. rubra'' blooms are associated with higher levels of [[bacteria]], dissolved organic nutrients, [[oxygen saturation]], particulate [[Total organic carbon|organic carbon]] and nitrogen.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Wilkerson|first=Frances P.|last2=Grunseich|first2=Gary|date=1990-01-01|title=Formation of blooms by the symbiotic ciliate Mesodinium rubrum: the significance of nitrogen uptake|url=https://doi.org/10.1093/plankt/12.5.973|journal=Journal of Plankton Research|language=en|volume=12|issue=5|pages=973–989|doi=10.1093/plankt/12.5.973|issn=0142-7873}}</ref> Specifically in the Columbia River estuary, red blooms correspond with increased [[Productivity (ecology)|secondary production]] by [[microbes]] and decreased [[ammonium]], [[nitrate]], and dissolved organic carbon levels.<ref name=":22" /> A further study in the Columbia River estuary found that high concentrations of organic nutrients and low amounts of inorganic nitrogen were associated with the red waters.<ref name=":14" /> ''M. rubra'' blooms also created areas characterized by high primary production and increased levels of [[particulate organic matter]] during this period, thus shifting the [[Trophic level|trophic]] status in red water areas from net [[heterotroph]]y towards [[Autotroph|autotrophy,]]<ref name=":14" /> making ''M. rubra''<nowiki/>'s red blooms a seasonal [[Biogeochemistry|biogeochemical]] [[Biodiversity hotspot|hotspot]] of the Columbia River estuary.<ref name=":14" />
== Anthropogenic impacts on processes == Nutrient cycling is affected by human alteration refereed to as [[Anthropogenic effect|anthropogeni]]<nowiki/>c impacts. The Columbia River Basin is home to nearly five million residents, and the rapid alteration of land in the past several centuries has shifted many aspects of nutrient dynamics within this environment. Human processes such as construction (such as for dams), [[logging]], and [[mining]] can impact [[sediment]] transport, resulting in decreased accumulation and/or the enhancement or removal of nutrients.<ref name=":3" /><ref name=":5" /><ref name=":4" /> The cycling of nutrients within the Columbia River Basin is also affected by differences in [[Land use|land-use]] through variability in human development and vegetation. Land use of the basin within the United States is primarily forested (87 percent), with 11 percent of land used for agriculture, and 2 percent for urban areas.<ref name=":10" />
=== Agriculture === Human-related activity has contributed over 50 percent of the available global reactive nitrogen.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Galloway|first=James N.|last2=Cowling|first2=Ellis B.|date=2002-03-01|title=Reactive Nitrogen and The World: 200 Years of Change|url=http://www.bioone.org/doi/abs/10.1579/0044-7447-31.2.64|journal=AMBIO: A Journal of the Human Environment|volume=31|issue=2|pages=64–71|doi=10.1579/0044-7447-31.2.64|issn=0044-7447}}</ref> The [[Haber process|Haber-Bosch process]] is an artificial means of nitrogen fixation, producing over 450 million tons of ammonia per year.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.haber.co.za/haber-process/|title=Haber Process {{!}} Haber Transport|website=www.haber.co.za|language=en-GB|access-date=2017-11-04}}</ref> Much of this yield is used for agricultural purposes through [[fertilizer]]s. [[Agriculture|Agricultural]] sources of nitrogen reach rivers primarily through the erosion of soil sediments, but also through airborne dust and gaseous transport of [[Volatility (chemistry)|volatilized]] [[Ammonia|NH<sub>3</sub>]] from livestock manure and fertilizers.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.nrcs.usda.gov/wps/portal/nrcs/detail/national/landuse/crops/?cid=nrcs143_014202|title=Fate and Transport of Nutrients: Nitrogen {{!}} NRCS|website=www.nrcs.usda.gov|language=en|access-date=2017-11-07}}</ref>
At the beginning of the twentieth century, agriculture began to exceed [[mining]] and became the Columbia River Basin's primary economic industry.<ref name=":18">{{Cite book|url=https://doi.org/10.17226/10962|title=Managing the Columbia River: Instream Flows, Water Withdrawals, and Salmon Survival|last=|first=|date=|publisher=National Research Council|year=2004|isbn=9780309091558|location=|pages=|language=en|doi=10.17226/10962}}</ref> The Columbia River has been subject to cultural [[eutrophication]] in part due to the use of the river and its tributaries to [[Irrigation|irrigate]] over seven million acres of farmland, an extraction that comprises an average of 93 percent of daily water use in the basin.<ref name=":18" /> Natural run-off caused by precipitation and [[snowpack]] melt across agricultural lands further transports more of these nutrients into the river.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.nwcouncil.org/history/Chronology|title=Columbia River Chronology|access-date=2017-11-04|language=en}}</ref> In the late 1990s, the nitrogen load in the Columbia river was over twice the concentration historically observed.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=|first=|date=|title=Nitrogen and Phosphorus in Large Rivers|url=https://cfpub.epa.gov/roe/|journal=EPA Report on the Environment|volume=|pages=|via=}}</ref>
=== Logging === [[Forest]]s are important [[Terrestrial plant|terrestrial]] sinks for nutrients due to the ability of vegetation to sequester excess nutrients into their biomass.<ref name=":19">{{Cite book|title=Maintaining the Long-term Productivity of Pacific Norhtwest Forest Ecosystems|last=Miller|first=Richard E.|publisher=College of Forestry|year=1989|isbn=|location=Corvallis, OR|pages=98–136}}</ref> Additionally, plant roots stabilize soils and consequently prevent a large portion of the nutrient pool to be transferred via runoff into rivers and other waterways.<ref name=":19" /> Studies of nearby Pacific Northwest forests have found that [[Logging|logged]] forests lose 1.6 to 3 times the amount of nutrients over several years times compared to undisturbed areas.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Fredriksen|first=R. L.|date=1971|title=Comparative chemical water quality--natural and disturbed streams following logging and slash burning|url=|journal=Forest land uses and stream environment|publisher=Oregon State University|volume=|pages=125–137|via=}}</ref> By 1992, 35 percent of the total harvestable forest in the Columbia River Basin had been logged.<ref name=":18" /> Consequently, though direct quantification of these processes within the Columbia River watershed have not yet occurred, the ubiquitous changes in land-use by the logging industry have changed the delivery of nutrients into the system.
=== Sewage and septic inputs === A significant nutrient source from developed areas into [[aquatic ecosystem]]s is through [[sewage]] and [[Septic tank|septic]] systems. [[Municipal waste]], high in nitrogen and phosphorus, is sometimes treated by wastewater facilities or through soil filtration, but often some excess nutrients leak and contribute to eutrophication.<ref name=":20">{{Cite web|url=http://www.wri.org/our-work/project/eutrophication-and-hypoxia/sources-eutrophication|title=Sources of Eutrophication {{!}} World Resources Institute|website=www.wri.org|language=en|access-date=2017-12-05}}</ref> Human sewage waste in the United States accounts for about 12 percent of average annual nitrogen input into rivers.<ref name=":20" /> Often, there are many small-scale sources of this discharge and no one input is clearly dominating nutrient loading. However, occasionally unexpected events, usually through sewer systems or at wastewater plants, occur that result in a significant singular emission. In the fall of 2017 for example, a power failure at a treatment facility in [[Vancouver, Washington]] led to the discharge of over 510,000 gallons of wholly untreated and partially treatment [[effluent]].<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.columbian.com/news/2017/oct/05/sewage-flows-into-columbia-r-after-power-failure-at-vancouver-treatment-plant/|title=Sewage flows into Columbia River after power failure at Vancouver treatment plant|date=2017-10-05|work=The Columbian|access-date=2017-12-05|language=en}}</ref> The continuing background discharge along with larger-scale, periodic emission events comprise a large input of human-derived nutrient loading.
=== Effects of dams === [[File:Columbia.png|thumb|382x382px|Map of Columbia River Basin showing locations of dams throughout the basin. The large number of dams has had measurable and lasting impact on the nutrient cycling thought the basin <ref name=":3" /><ref name=":9" /> - dams shown in red and yellow.]]Beginning in the 1930s with the construction of the [[Bonneville Dam|Bonneville]] and [[Grand Coulee Dam|Grand Coulee]] dams, the Columbia River has experienced significant modification to its flow. Today, the [[United States Army Corps of Engineers|US Army Corps of Engineers]] recognize over 250 [[reservoir]]s, 150 [[Hydroelectricity|hydroelectric]] projects, and 18 [[Mainstem (hydrology)|mainstem]] dams on the Columbia and its main tributary, the [[Snake River]].<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.nwd.usace.army.mil/Media/Fact-Sheets/Fact-Sheet-Article-View/Article/475820/columbia-river-basin-dams/|title=Columbia River Basin Dams|last=|first=|date=|website=US Army Corps of Engineers|access-date=2017-11-25}}</ref> [[Dam]]s have been shown to directly impact nutrient cycling within the Columbia river basin through the formation of reservoirs which dramatically alter river [[hydrology]] and discharge rates and as a result constitute a major anthroprogenic impact on nutrient cycling in the river.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Palmer|first=Margaret A|last2=Reidy Liermann|first2=Catherine A|last3=Nilsson|first3=Christer|last4=Flörke|first4=Martina|last5=Alcamo|first5=Joseph|last6=Lake|first6=P Sam|last7=Bond|first7=Nick|date=2008-03-01|title=Climate change and the world's river basins: anticipating management options|url=http://onlinelibrary.wiley.com/doi/10.1890/060148/abstract|journal=Frontiers in Ecology and the Environment|language=en|volume=6|issue=2|pages=81–89|doi=10.1890/060148|issn=1540-9309}}</ref><ref name=":9" /><ref>{{Cite journal|last=Dauble|first=D. D.|last2=Hanrahan|first2=T. P.|last3=Geist|first3=D. R.|last4=Parsley|first4=M. J.|date=2003-08-01|title=Impacts of the Columbia River Hydroelectric System on Main-Stem Habitats of Fall Chinook Salmon|url=http://afs.tandfonline.com/doi/abs/10.1577/M02-013|journal=North American Journal of Fisheries Management|volume=23|issue=3|pages=641–659|doi=10.1577/M02-013|issn=0275-5947}}</ref><ref>{{Cite journal|last=Payne|first=Jeffrey T.|last2=Wood|first2=Andrew W.|last3=Hamlet|first3=Alan F.|last4=Palmer|first4=Richard N.|last5=Lettenmaier|first5=Dennis P.|date=2004-01-01|title=Mitigating the Effects of Climate Change on the Water Resources of the Columbia River Basin|url=https://link.springer.com/article/10.1023/B:CLIM.0000013694.18154.d6|journal=Climatic Change|language=en|volume=62|issue=1-3|pages=233–256|doi=10.1023/B:CLIM.0000013694.18154.d6|issn=0165-0009}}</ref> Due to its size and the large number of dams within the basin, the Columbia River basin is often used as representative case study on how dams an impact nutrient cycling of watersheds in general. Notably, dam construction in the Columbia River Basin has impacted relative nutrient ratios, methane production, and salmon migration. [[File:Cascades rapids.jpg|thumb|Cascades Rapids prior to construction of the Bonneville Dam.]] To provide context for the scale of change that dams can effect, the construction of the [[Bonneville Dam|Bonneville dam]] in the late 1930s completely submerged the [[Cascades Rapids]], permanently changing the local river hydrology and subsequently altering local nutrient transport and processes in the region.<ref name=":9" /> The restriction of flow as well as the creation of standing water upriver of the dams have been linked to deleterious effects on nutrient cycling in similar ecosystems, such as the [[Murray River|Murray River Basin]] in Australia and the [[Danube|Danube River Basin]] in Europe, through processes such as the alteration of particle [[Residence time (fluid dynamics)|residence times]] and [[Eutrophication|nutrient loading]].<ref>{{Cite journal|last=GALLOWAY|first=JAMES N.|last2=ABER|first2=JOHN D.|last3=ERISMAN|first3=JAN WILLEM|last4=SEITZINGER|first4=SYBIL P.|last5=HOWARTH|first5=ROBERT W.|last6=COWLING|first6=ELLIS B.|last7=COSBY|first7=B. JACK|date=2003-04-01|title=The Nitrogen Cascade|url=https://academic.oup.com/bioscience/article/53/4/341-356/250178|journal=BioScience|language=en|volume=53|issue=4|doi=10.1641/0006-3568(2003)053[0341:tnc]2.0.co;2|issn=0006-3568}}</ref> [[File:Corps-engineers-archives bonneville dam looking east.jpg|thumb|Arial image of Bonneville dam showing reservoir. Notice the widening of the river and calm water upstream of the dam as compared to the pre-dam photo of the Cascades Rapids.]]
==== Nutrient ratios ==== [[Macronutrients]], such as [[phosphorus]], [[nitrogen]], and [[silicate]] are strongly impacted by increased residence times in reservoirs created by dam construction throughout the Columbia River Basin.<ref name=":9" /> Exact nutrient retention rates can vary between 16 and 98 percent depending on local hydrology, reservoir design, and location in the basin.<ref name=":9" /> However, this increase in nutrient retention rates in the Columbia River basin has generally modified the relative ratios of available nutrients from their natural state, which has subsequently altered the efficiency of compound usage by [[primary producers]] such as [[diatom]]s.<ref name=":9" />
Diatoms are directly affected by the [[hydrodynamic]] changes that reservoirs create. The slow moving, fresh water in reservoirs facilitates high settling rates for [[siliceous]] diatom shells, which can both bloom in the reservoir or be carried into the river from upstream.<ref name=":9" /> Diatom shells are negatively [[Buoyancy|buoyant]] and have a natural tenancy to settle, this coupled with the reduced forward momentum of standing water in a reservoir, and the physical barrier a dam increase the settling rate of diatom shells within the reservoir.<ref name=":9" /> This high settling rate, coupled with slow dissolution of silicate in freshwater, leads to a net decrease in silicate recycling and reduced silicate transport through the Columbia River Basin and export out of the estuary resulting in a net decrease in the overall silicate budget.<ref name=":9" />
These same hydrodynamic changes also result in a net increase in phosphorus and nitrogen recycling in reservoirs.<ref name=":9" /> Settling rates for algae, other than diatoms, are slow.<ref name=":9" /> Slow settling rates allow for algae to remain in the water column longer, allowing for increased release for organically bound phosphorus and nitrogen into the water column through [[Remineralisation|remineralization]].<ref name=":9" />
The combine impact of increased silicate retention and increased remineralization of phosphorus and nitrogen can result in high N/Si and P/Si ratios within and below reservoirs; these increased rations can be further compounded by increase nitrogen and phosphorus concentrations from [[eutrophication]].<ref name=":9" /> The high N/Si and P/Si rations caused by these processes can be harmful to the local ecosystem in the basin; for example, N/Si ratios greater than 1 can result in excess nitrogen relative to diatom requirements, this can promote the growth of other phytoplankton species, negatively affecting diatom communities.<ref name=":9" />
This impact of reservoirs on the transport and recycling of silicate, phosphorus, and nitrogen, is not unique to the Columbia River Basin, but has had a measurable impact on the export of these nutrients through the basin and out of the estuary.<ref name=":3" /><ref name=":9" /> As discussed in context with the [[Pacific decadal oscillation|PDO]] and [[El Niño–Southern Oscillation|ENSO]], since 1858, total silicate export out of the Columbia river basin through the estuary has decreased over 50 percent with about 40 percent of that reduction liked directly to dam construction.<ref name=":3" /> Finally, as discussed above, these changed in nutrient ratios have largely contributed to the greening of the Columbia river estuary.
==== Methane ==== Reservoirs often serve as a [[catchment basin]] for organic matter such as vegetation, and waste transferred into the river via rainwater runoff. Initially, this organic matter provides a nutrient source; however, as it continues to accumulate and begins to decompose, the [[respiration (physiology)|respiration]] of this organic matter can quickly deplete oxygen levels leading to [[Anoxic waters|anoxia]]. Under anoxic conditions, the large amount of organic matter are further broken down through [[anaerobic respiration]] and [[methanogenesis]] into carbon dioxide (CO<sub>2</sub>) and methane (CH<sub>4</sub>).<ref name=":9" /> These decomposition processes can occur rapidly after flooding, when large amount of fresh organic matter are transported into the river, and as a result methane and carbon dioxide release can be large.<ref name=":9" />
Anaerobic respiration, which occurs in the absence of highly [[Redox|oxidizing]] molecular oxygen, utilizes less-oxidized [[electron acceptors]] such as [[nitrate]] (NO<sub>3</sub><sup>−</sup>). As a result, high levels of anaerobic respiration can result in [[denitrification]]. This process of denitrification removes nitrogen from the Columbia River Basin, by converting available nitrogen, important for primary production, from its usable dissolved forms (i.e. NO<sub>3</sub><sup>−</sup> and NO<sub>2</sub><sup>−</sup>) to its gaseous form (N<sub>2</sub>).<ref name=":9" />
==== Salmon migration ==== Dams provide a barrier for migrating fish such as salmon, limiting their abilities to swim upstream. As discussed above, studies in the Pacific Northwest and Scandinavia have demonstrated that migratory fish can provide 30 percent or more of the phosphorus input to [[oligotrophic lake]]s.<ref name=":9" /> These rates of phosphorus fertilization, as well as similarly high rates of nitrogen fertilization, come from the decomposition of adult carcasses after mating and can be significantly affected by reduced migration caused by dam construction.<ref name=":9" /> Research estimates as much as 7 to 15 percent of the migrating salmon stock perish as they cross each consecutive dam.<ref name=":11" /> Lower rates of successful salmon migration redistribute the remineralization of nitrogen and phosphorus by reducing nitrogen and phosphorus fertilization upstream of dams, as a result there is a successive reduction in nutrients upstream of each consecutive dam.<ref name=":9" /> The redistribution of nutrients in the Columbia River Basin is currently a popular area of research; however, additional data is needed to determine the lasting implications of these changes.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Naiman|first=Robert J.|last2=Bilby|first2=Robert E.|last3=Schindler|first3=Daniel E.|last4=Helfield|first4=James M.|date=2002-06-01|title=Pacific Salmon, Nutrients, and the Dynamics of Freshwater and Riparian Ecosystems|url=https://link.springer.com/article/10.1007/s10021-001-0083-3|journal=Ecosystems|language=en|volume=5|issue=4|pages=399–417|doi=10.1007/s10021-001-0083-3|issn=1432-9840}}</ref>
== Water quality == The complexity of [[nutrient cycle]]s is an enduring challenge to understanding [[ecosystem]] function. Particularly, in areas of significant habitation and modification by humans, these systems are experiencing rapid periods of alteration from historical precedents within the Columbia river Basin.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://nca2014.globalchange.gov/report/sectors/biogeochemical-cycles|title=Climate Change Impacts in the United States - Biogeochemical Cycles|last=Galloway|first=James|last2=Schlesinger|first2=William|date=2014|website=National Climate Assessment|access-date=2017-12-04}}</ref> These shifts in human habitation and impact have further complicated and obscured insights into the behavior of nutrient cycling. As the dominant water system in the Pacific Northwest and the home to nearly five million people, the Columbia River Basin integrates these numerous natural and anthropogenic biogeochemical processes.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://pubs.usgs.gov/sir/2007/5186/section3.html|title=Nutrient and Suspended-Sediment Transport and Trends in the Columbia River and Puget Sound Basins, 1993–2003|last=Sobieszczyk|first=By Daniel R. Wise, Frank A. Rinella III, Joseph F. Rinella, Greg J. Fuhrer, Sandra S. Embrey, Gregory M. Clark, Gregory E. Schwarz, and Steven|date=2007|website=pubs.usgs.gov|publisher=U.S. Geological Survey|language=en|access-date=2017-12-04}}</ref> Consequently, the watershed is a foundational environmental resource, providing the region with many goods and services including jobs, natural materials (timber, fresh water), and recreation at a capital worth recently estimated to be $198 billion annually.<ref>{{Cite book|url=http://onlinelibrary.wiley.com/doi/10.1002/9781118643525.ch17/summary|title=River Science|last=Alan Yeakley|first=J.|last2=Ervin|first2=David|last3=Chang|first3=Heejun|last4=Granek|first4=Elise F.|last5=Dujon|first5=Veronica|last6=Shandas|first6=Vivek|last7=Brown|first7=Darrell|date=2016|publisher=John Wiley & Sons, Ltd|isbn=9781118643525|editor-last=Gilvear|editor-first=David J.|pages=335–352|language=en|doi=10.1002/9781118643525.ch17|editor-last2=Greenwood|editor-first2=lcolm T.|editor-last3=Thoms|editor-first3=rtin C.|editor-last4=Wood|editor-first4=Paul J.}}</ref> However, the efficacy and ability of the system to provide these assets largely hinges upon the function of such essential ecosystem components like nutrient cycling. Perturbations to nutrient cycling may result in deleterious effects to both the environment and to resident human populations, possibly through the emergence of toxic plankton blooms, decreased aesthetic value, dissolved oxygen depletion, and reduced fish stocks.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.pdx.edu/columbia-basin/threats-to-water-sustainability-in-the-columbia-basin|title=Threats to water sustainability in the Columbia Basin|last=|first=|date=2017|website=www.pdx.edu|publisher=Portland State University|access-date=2017-12-04}}</ref> Ultimately, the sustainability of the Columbia River Basin ecosystem and its impact on residents are firmly connected by the function of nutrient cycles.

{{about|the semiotic analysis topic|the company|OpenText}} {{confused|OpenDocument}} In [[semiotic]] analysis (the studies of signs or symbols), an '''open text''' is a text that allows multiple or mediated [[Hermeneutics|interpretation]] by the readers. In contrast, a closed text leads the reader to one intended interpretation.
The concept of the '''open text''' comes from [[Umberto Eco]]'s collection of essays ''The Role of the Reader'',<ref>Eco, U., 1984,The Role of the Reader: Explorations in the Semiotics of Texts, Indiana University Press, {{ISBN|0-253-20318-X}}</ref> but it is also derivative of [[Roland Barthes]]'s distinction between 'readerly' (lisible) and 'writerly' (scriptible) texts as set out in his 1968 essay, "[[The Death of the Author]]".<ref>Barthes, R., 1977, 'The Death of the Author' in Image-Music-Text, Fontana</ref>
== Content == {{refimprove|date=November 2018}} In this essay, [[Umberto Eco]] describes a special kind of musical works that can be organized and re-organized by the performers before they are played to the audience. He then applied this idea of "open works" to literary texts and other works of art.
Every work of art can be read, according to Eco, in three distinct ways: the moral, the allegorical and the [[Anagoge|anagogical]]. Each is not only distinct but can be fully anticipated and directed by the author (or the artist) of the work. An example of this kind of reading is found in the stories by [[Franz Kafka|Kafka]], in which his symbolic actions cannot be read in one definitive way; each reading will end up with similar and multiple meanings.
The reader will read a certain work differently every time, depending on his/her emotional state, physical state and political world view. We can find an example of this in plays written by [[Bertolt Brecht|Brecht]] , which are "open" in the same way that an argument between two people is open: both sides (the actors and the viewers) want and anticipate a solution at the end, but no solution ever comes, leaving us to wander to find meaning.
[[Umberto Eco]] makes a distinction between these kind of works, which are "open" in their interpretation, to the musical works from the beginning, which are open in their structural sense. These kind of "openness" is not only for musical works, it might be any kind of artistic work (painting, poem, performance etc.)
This kind of "openness" is derived from the science of the time, he says. When people believed in a [[Geocentric model|geocentric]] world, they expected every work of art to have only one definitive interpretation, but as people found out about the universe and the magnitude of stars in the sky and their hierarchy, they began to expect more ideas to be interpreted from every work.
He continues by comparing open works to [[Quantum mechanics]], and he arrives at the conclusion that open works are more like [[Albert Einstein|Einstein]]'s idea of the universe, which is governed by precise laws but seems random at first. The artist in those open works arranges the work carefully so it could be re-organized by another but still keep the original voice or intent of the artist.
Every work can be read in infinite ways, depending on an individual's state of mind and perspective, and it also depends on a third person intervention, either the players of the orchestra or the curator at the museum. Eco understand the difficulties with this perspective, but he ends by saying that this article, as all works, is still a "work in movement", an "open work" and still a "work in progress".
